Question:

Answer:
What is the difference between acquiescence in conformity and acquiescence in conformity with the truths?
A discussion arises from a discussion.
For what reason is acquiescence said to be acquiescence in conformity with the truths, but heat and summit are not?
Some say: Just as acquiescence is said to be in conformity with the truths, so too should heat and summit be said.
But since they are not said, one should know that all of this is incomplete speech.
Moreover, some say: Conformity means to follow along. That acquiescence well follows along, but heat and summit do not.
Moreover, some say: The dharma of heat can stop the superior delusion regarding the truths, the summit stops the delusion in the middle, and acquiescence stops the lower delusion.
Because it stops the delusion in the body, the supreme worldly dharmas arise.

Moreover, some say: The dharma of heat can give rise to the lower illumination regarding the truths, the summit gives rise to the illumination in the middle, and acquiescence gives rise to the superior illumination.
Because in this body there is clear understanding of the conditioned truths, it can give rise to the supreme worldly dharmas.
There are also those who say that the heat dharma is delighted with the aggregates, the summit dharma is delighted with the jewels, and the forbearance dharma is delighted with the truths.
Because of contemplating the delight in the body with regard to the holy truths, it can give rise to the supreme worldly dharmas.

There are also those who say that forbearance is similar to the path of seeing at all times. Just as the path of seeing is only the mindfulness of dharmas present at all times, so too is that forbearance.
Heat and summit are not like this.
Why is it so?
Because one first cultivates the mindfulness of dharmas, and later the three mindfulnesses increase and appear one after another, therefore they are not similar.

Forbearance cultivates the mindfulness of dharmas and only increases the mindfulness of dharmas, because it is similar to the path of seeing, it is called the forbearance that accords with the truths.
Heat and summit are not like this, and are not called that which accords with the truths.
There are also those who say that the forbearance dharma is close to the path of seeing, while heat and summit are not.
There is another explanation: the stage of acquiescence also has many continuities and also appears in a single moment, while heat and summit only appear in many continuities.
There is another explanation: the stage of acquiescence is only one definite thought, while heat and summit are not so.
There is another explanation: the stage of acquiescence is pure observation without mixture, while heat and summit have mixture, and sometimes wholesome roots of the desire realm are produced.

There is another explanation: the stage of acquiescence is neither much nor extensive in pure observation, but is able to follow and head towards nirvana, while heat and summit are both much and extensive in pure observation, and are also able to follow and head towards nirvana.
Here it should be explained using the analogy of turning and buying a maá¹‡i jewel.

superior acquiescence practices the four aspects and takes the truth of suffering as its object.
There is another explanation: superior acquiescence takes the truth of the path as its object.
Question:
What dharmas does patience take as its object in order to attain correct determination?
Answer:
Some say it takes the truth of the path as its object.
Question:
If so, why does it not take the inverted aspects as its object?
If it takes the inverted aspects as its object, why does it not create obstacles for attaining correct determination?
Answer:
Even if it takes the inverted aspects as its object, it does not create obstacles for correct determination.
Why is this?
Because in cultivating these wholesome roots, there is a prior direct route as an object. Therefore, when entering the noble path, one is able to freely use this as an object.

For example, in the path of seeing, one first gives rise to the path of patience and knowledge in the desire realm, then gives rise to the path of patience and knowledge in the peak of existence. After the path of patience and knowledge in the peak of existence, one again gives rise to the path of patience and knowledge in the desire realm that contemplates the aspect of suffering. Later, one gives rise to the contemplation of the aspect of accumulation, and so on at length.
All of this is called taking the inverted aspects as its object.
It does not cause obstacles to seeing the truth by mistakenly inverting the objects and practices.
Why is this?
Because in seeing the truth, the objects and practices have already been well-trodden.
The same is true for endurance. It does not cause obstacles to attaining right determination.
Those who say that after the supreme forbearance with regard to the truth of the path, one attains right determination,
they should have three minds with the same object, namely the supreme worldly dharmas, the endurance of the dharma of suffering, and the knowledge of the dharma of suffering;
two minds should have the same practice but not the same object, namely the subsequent endurance and subsequent knowledge of suffering;
two minds have the same object but not the same practice, namely the endurance of the dharma of accumulation and the knowledge of the dharma of accumulation.
The judges say:
It should be said that after the supreme forbearance with regard to the truth of suffering, one attains right determination.
That path of seeing is a powerful wholesome root. Although it mistakenly inverts the objects and practices, it does not cause obstacles to right determination.
That patience is a mundane wholesome root with a weak nature. If it encounters obstacles, it will create difficulties for the path of seeing.

The correct meaning is that one should contemplate the patience of the superior truth of suffering, and then attain right determination. It is not that one first contemplates the patience of the path of truth and then attains right determination.
The patience of the superior truth practices the truth of suffering and endures the path of skillful means, extensively practicing the sixteen aspects and contemplating the four noble truths.

That practitioner correctly contemplates the suffering of the desire realm, contemplates the suffering of the form and formless realms, the accumulation of practices in the desire realm, the accumulation of practices in the form and formless realms, the cessation of practices in the desire realm, the cessation of practices in the form and formless realms, the path that cuts off practices in the desire realm, and the path that cuts off practices in the form and formless realms. These thirty-two minds are called the lower patience.

Later, the practitioner gradually reduces the practice and objects, and again correctly contemplates the suffering of the desire realm and the suffering of the form and formless realms, up to contemplating the path that eliminates the practices of the desire realm, excluding the contemplation of the path that eliminates the practices of the form and formless realms. From this, it is called middle acceptance.

Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm and the suffering of the form and formless realms, up to contemplating the cessation of the practices of the form and formless realms, excluding all paths.

Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm and the suffering of the form and formless realms, up to contemplating the cessation of the practices of the desire realm, excluding the cessation of the practices of the form and formless realms.
Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm up to the contemplation of the arising of the practices of the form and formless realms, excluding all cessations.

Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm up to the contemplation of the arising of the practices of the desire realm, excluding the arising of the practices of the form and formless realms.

Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm, excluding the suffering of the form and formless realms.

He further correctly contemplates the suffering of the desire realm, continuously and uninterruptedly, without being far removed from it. When contemplating in this way, he deeply gives rise to revulsion.
He further reduces it, only forming two thoughts to contemplate a single aspect.
Like the receptivity to the cognition of the factors of the truth of suffering and the cognition of the factors of the truth of suffering.
Correctly contemplating in this way is called middling receptivity.
He further contemplates the suffering of the desire realm with a single thought, which is called upper receptivity, followed by the subsequent arising of the highest worldly dharmas.
After the highest worldly dharmas, the receptivity to the cognition of the factors of the truth of suffering arises next.

It is like a person who wishes to leave his own country and go to another country. He has much wealth, property, and possessions, but he cannot take them with him. He exchanges these possessions for money.
He still finds them too much and cannot take them with him, so he exchanges the money for gold.
He still finds it too much and cannot take it with him, so he exchanges the gold for many valuable jewels.
He takes these jewels and goes to the other country as he pleases.

In this way, the practitioner gradually abandons [the stages] and is not separated from the continuum, giving rise to the upper patience. After patience, the supreme worldly dharmas are subsequently born. After the supreme worldly dharmas, the patience of the dharma of suffering is subsequently born.

Those who attain right determination after the patience that takes suffering as its object in the four [stages] must have the same practice and the same object, namely, the supreme patience, the supreme worldly dharmas, the patience of the dharma of suffering, and the knowledge of the dharma of suffering.
Two minds have the same practice but not the same object, namely, the patience of the subsequent [truth] of suffering and the knowledge of the subsequent [truth] of suffering.
Two minds have the same object but not the same practice, namely, the patience of the dharma of the [truth of] accumulation and the knowledge of the dharma of the [truth of] accumulation.

The question is asked:

There are also those who say that the lower ones should be called summits.

Question:
Why is it said that there is retrogression from the summit but not from the heat stage?
The answer is:
Some say that just as it is said that there is retrogression from the summit, so too should it be said that there is retrogression from the heat stage.
But since it is not said, one should know that all [the statements] are incomplete.
Furthermore, some say that when the practitioner is at the summit, there are many obstacles. There are many obstacles from the afflictions and karma of the three times.
From the summit up to the stage of acceptance, at that time the afflictions and karma of the evil destinies create many obstacles.
Why is it so?
Those afflictions think like this:
If that practitioner has already reached the stage of acceptance, in whose body will I give rise to the fruits of retribution again?
When one is free from the desire of the desire realm, the afflictions and karma of the desire realm create many obstacles.
Why is it so?
The afflictions and karma think like this:
If that practitioner leaves the desire realm, in whose body will I give rise to the fruits of retribution again?
When one is about to leave the desire realm of neither perception nor non-perception, the afflictions and karma of the future are often obstructive.
Why is this?
The afflictions and karma think like this:
If this practitioner has already left desire, they will no longer receive a body, and on whose body will I produce the retribution?
The practitioner has many obstacles during these three periods, and therefore it is said that there is falling back from the peak, but not falling back from heat.
There is also a view that at that time the practitioner gives rise to great sorrow, just like a person who sees a treasure trove, sees it and is delighted, thinking like this:
I will now permanently cut off the root of poverty.
Later, when they want to take it, it suddenly disappears. That person at that time gives rise to great sorrow over this treasure trove.

In the same way, when the practitioner abides in the peak dharma, they think to themselves that before long they will attain acceptance and permanently cut off the evil destinies, and their mind gives rise to joy, but later they fall back and give rise to great sorrow.
There is another explanation: If it is said that the summit has retrogression, it should be known that heat also has retrogression.
There is another explanation: Because the summit dharma does not abide for a long time, therefore it has retrogression.
There is another explanation: When one wishes to attain acceptance, one greatly gains heavy benefits.
Just as a sage does not fall into evil destinies, when one attains acceptance it is also like this.

Question:
What is the essence and characteristic of falling back from the peak?
Answer:
This is an unaccomplished nature, undiscerned and indeterminate, not associated with the mind, included in the aggregate of formations.
Furthermore, some say this is the essence of disbelief.
Why is it so?
If one has faith, one can attain it; if one lacks faith, one loses it.
There is another explanation: The nature of the defilements and entanglements that cause one to regress from the summit dharma is precisely the nature of those defilements and entanglements.
Those who explain it in this way also say it is the nature of defilement.
There is another explanation: The nature of a dharma that accords with the dharma of regression is precisely its nature.
If that is so, then all dharmas are the nature of regression.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas are conditions for the power of [the summit dharma].
The Venerable Buddhadeva said:
The nature of non-existence is the nature of regression, which is a strong discrimination without a corresponding object.
The accumulation of wholesome roots is called the summit, and the dispersion of wholesome roots is called regression. What other nature is there?
It is just like a person who has many possessions, and others rob him, causing him to become poor later on.
People ask him:
You are now poor, what is the nature of this?
That person answers:
I originally had wealth, but others robbed me, and now I am only poor. What kind of nature can I have?
It is also like a person whose clothes are torn. Others ask:
Your clothes are torn now, what kind of nature are they?
That person replies:
The clothes were originally complete and firm, but now they are torn. What other nature can they have?
It is also like a person who originally wore clothes, but others took them away.
Others ask:
You are now naked and have no clothes. What kind of nature are they?
That person replies:
I originally wore clothes, but others took them away. Now I am naked and have no clothes. What kind of nature can they have?
In this way, when the practitioner's wholesome roots gather, it is called the peak. Later, if they disperse, it is called falling back. What kind of nature can there be?
Therefore, the nature of non-existence is called the nature of falling back.
The judges say:
This should not be said. The previous explanation is better.
The nature of falling back from the peak is not accomplished, not hidden, not indeterminate, not associated with the mind, and is included in the aggregate of formations.

Just as when flowers are gathered in the summer and piled up, the heat generated by the flowers causes them to wither themselves.

The Venerable Ghoá¹£a said:

Just as the sign of the light of the sun is the first sign, the sun of undefiled cognition also has heat as its first sign. Therefore it is called heat.

Some also say that cessation and the path are the places of refuge, and therefore they are mentioned.

There is also an explanation that the Abhidharma speaks of faith in the three truths, and the Vinaya speaks of faith in the truth of cessation. This is also called heat, which can take the four truths as objects.
The author of the sutra cites the sutra as evidence, as it says:
The Buddha told the monks Masaka and PÅ«rá¹‡a:
I have four phrases of the Dharma, which I will explain to you.
Do you want to know?
I will satisfy your mind.
Those two people said:
We are now unfit vessels, so what is the use of knowing?
And so on, explaining in detail.
Question:
The Buddha deeply knew that those people were not yet able to receive the Dharma, so why did he say, I will satisfy your mind?
Answer:
Some say that people think that those people have no one to teach and transform them, so they create various evils and destroy themselves.
Therefore, the TathÄgata raised his hand and said:
What I should do, I have now done, but you yourself engage in deviant practices and destroy yourself. It is not because I do not teach and transform you.
There is another explanation: in order to stop the slander of non-Buddhists, he said, You may do as you wish.
If the TathÄgata had not told them, the non-Buddhists would have slandered him, saying:
How can the Greatly Compassionate One teach the Dharma to disciples who are obedient but not to those who are disobedient?
If the TathÄgata had told them, the non-Buddhists would not have slandered him.
There is another explanation: in order to stop the lack of faith among the ÅšÄkyas.
If the TathÄgata had not told them, the ÅšÄkyas would have given rise to a lack of faith, thinking:
Why does SiddhÄrtha not teach the Dharma to his relatives?
They would be jealous and worry that those people would be the same as themselves.
If the TathÄgata had told them, the ÅšÄkyas would not have given rise to a lack of faith at that time.
There is another explanation: that person himself engaged in misconduct. The TathÄgata took him as a witness and said to him:
You yourself engaged in misconduct both when you were a layperson and now that you have gone forth. This is not my fault.
At that time, the TathÄgata used gentle words to reproach him in front of others. Therefore, he said, You may do as you wish.

There is another explanation: in order to give rise to that person's future wholesome roots, the Buddha knew that although that person was not able to accept the teaching now, he would certainly give rise to wholesome roots of remorse in the future.
Why is it so?
That person thought:
The greatly compassionate one allowed me to do as I wished, but I did not accept it. This is not the TathÄgata's fault.
He was able to give rise to wholesome roots of remorse like this. For this reason, he would certainly leave the evil destinies.
There is another explanation: the Buddha knew that after that person's life ended, he would certainly be reborn among the dragons and experience great suffering. He then thought:
Where did I originally come from to be reborn here?
He knew that he had originally left home to join the Buddha's teachings.
Next, he thought:
There is no one to transform me. I should now go and do unbeneficial things, destroy Buddha stupas and monasteries, and kill the monks.
At that time, by the Buddha's spiritual power, an image of the TathÄgata appeared before him and said:
AÅ›vajit and PÅ«rá¹‡a!
Do you wish to know the four phrases of the Dharma that I have?
You should know that this suffering is your fault, not mine.
I have done what I should have done, but now you are acting wrongly on your own.
In order to stop the dragon's angry entanglements and make him protect the Buddha's teachings, he said, You may do as you wish.
Question:
What are called the four phrases of the Dharma?
Answer:
Some say it is the Dharma of the Four Truths.
Why is it so?
Because those two people committed those evil deeds because they had not seen the truth.
There are also those who say it is the four establishments of mindfulness.
Why is it so?
Because those two people create this evil conduct due to their delusions.
There are also those who say it is the four right efforts.
Why is it so?
Because those two people create this evil conduct due to their much laziness.
There are also those who say it is the four bases of supernatural power.
Why is it so?
Because those two people create this evil conduct due to their inability to accumulate wholesome dharmas.
There are also those who say it is the four noble lineages.
Why is it so?
Because those two people create this evil conduct due to their greed for offerings.
There are also those who say it is the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Why is it so?
Because those two people create this evil conduct by saying they have attained the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a when in reality they have not attained them.

There are also those who say it is the four wholesome dharmas: well knowing the realms, well knowing the sense bases, well knowing dependent origination, and well knowing what is possible and impossible.
Why is this?
Because those two people are ignorant of cause and effect, and therefore commit evil deeds.
There is also a saying, as stated in the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢gama:
In the teachings of the sages, good words are the best. Always speak lovingly, and avoid what is unloving.
Always speak truthfully, and avoid falsehood. Always speak in accordance with the Dharma, and avoid what is contrary to the Dharma.
This is called the four.
There is also a saying, as stated in the EkottarÃ¢gama:
Non-greed, non-hatred, right mindfulness, and right concentration are called the four.
They said:
What use is it for us to know this teaching?
The World-Honored One said:
You foolish people, far from my teachings, you do not even have the slightest trace of the Dharma of warmth.
Question:
Why did those two people say this:
What use is it for us to know this teaching?
Answer:
Some say that person knows himself to be not a Dharma vessel, heading towards the good path is still not a vessel, let alone heading towards nirvana to be a vessel.

Moreover, some say that various evil practices are frequently committed in that person's body, violating the precepts. Knowing that this body is not a Dharma vessel, even clay and stone can cause sprouts to grow, but my body now will never be able to give rise to the factors of liberation.
Moreover, some say that person has already created determined karma.

Moreover, some say that person has already approached the dharmas of retribution, the signs of that person's evil path retribution have already appeared before him, up to the flowing out of water from the ten fingers.
Moreover, some say that the Buddha predicted that person will attain the enlightenment of a pratyekabuddha.
He thinks like this:
Why bother the TathÄgata to teach me the Dharma? I will never be able to enter right concentration in this present life.
For these various causes and conditions, he says this:
What use do I have in knowing this Dharma?
The World-Honored One said:
Those foolish people who are far removed from my Dharma, in my true Dharma and Vinaya, do not even possess a trace of the Dharma of warmth.
Question:
There are many kinds of Vinaya:

Sometimes there is Vinaya for time, Vinaya for place, Vinaya for family lineage, Vinaya for household rules, Vinaya for punishing offenses, Vinaya for transgressions, Vinaya for clarity, Vinaya for the noble ones, Vinaya for desire, anger, and delusion.
Which Vinaya is being discussed here?
Answer:
Some say that here it is discussing the Vinaya for the noble ones.
Some say that here it is discussing the Vinaya for desire, anger, and delusion.
Question:
Do all those who do not attain the Dharma of warmth have the same fate as AÅ›vakÄ« and PÅ«rá¹‡a?
Answer:
Not all of them.
There are generally three kinds of sentient beings:
First, those with a fixed intention;
Second, the mind of elimination;
Third, the mind of cutting off.
Those with the mind of expectation are those who purely uphold the precepts.
Those with the mind of elimination are arhats whose tasks are already accomplished.
Those with the mind of cutting off are those who violate the precepts.
Because they have neither the mind of expectation nor the mind of elimination, but only the mind of cutting off, therefore the World-Honored One rebukes them.
Other sentient beings with the mind of cutting off are the same as them.
As it is said:
Up to not having even a little bit of the dharma of warmth.
Question:
This warmth good root is the most supreme and subtle, abiding in the ground of tranquility, why is it said to be little now?
Answer:
Because it is the smallest among the good roots of the stage of penetration, it is said to be little.

There is also an explanation that because these arise after the wholesome roots of the aggregate of views, they are called the aggregate of views. The wholesome roots of mindfulness of breathing, impurity, and the four establishments of mindfulness are referred to as the aggregate of views.

These four kinds of wholesome roots, namely the dharmas of heat, the dharmas of summit, the dharmas of patience, and the supreme worldly dharmas, are called the factors leading to penetration, also called contemplating the truths, also called cultivation, also called wholesome roots.

As for the factors leading to penetration, the uncontaminated noble path is penetration. These wholesome roots accord with that dharma, are the wings of that dharma, and are the nature and category of that dharma, thus they are called the factors leading to penetration.
As for contemplating the truths, by means of the aspects of impermanence, etc., one contemplates and examines the truths, thus it is called contemplating the truths.
As for cultivation, in order to seek the noble path and its fruits, one cultivates and purifies this body, removing impurities and desires to make it a vessel of the Dharma.
It is just as farmers, in order to seek the fruits of their labor, cultivate and purify the fields, removing the weeds.
They are also like this, thus it is called cultivation.
As for the roots of goodness, the noble path is called goodness, and nirvÄá¹‡a is called the fruit.
These various dharmas are the initial basis for establishing that, and are therefore called the roots of goodness.
Question:
What are the differences between these roots of goodness such as heat?
Answer:
The dharma of heat can stop the superior delusion regarding the truths as objects, up to being able to stop the delusion in the body, and thus gives rise to the supreme worldly dharmas.

Furthermore, some say that the dharma of heat can give rise to the slight illumination regarding the truths as objects, up to the illumination regarding the truths as objects in the body, and thus gives rise to the supreme worldly dharmas.

Furthermore, the dharma of heat can give rise to the slight faith regarding the truths as objects, the dharma of summit gives rise to middling faith, and the dharma of patience gives rise to superior faith.
Because there is this faith in the body, it can give rise to the supreme worldly dharmas.
Furthermore, the dharma of heat is delighted with the aggregates, up to being delighted with the body, and thus gives rise to the supreme worldly dharmas.

There is also a view that heat is the entry point for the foundations of mindfulness, and the peak is the entry point for the dharmas of heat. Acceptance is the entry point for the dharmas of the peak, and the supreme worldly dharmas are the entry point for acceptance.
In this way, the sequence is uninterrupted, and it is the same.
The Venerable Ghoá¹£a says:
These wholesome roots, two are in the desire realm, namely heat and peak;
two are in the form realm, namely acceptance and supreme worldly dharmas.
The judges say:
This should not be said, because these are in the form realm, they are the ground of concentration, and they are able to cultivate the practices of the noble ones and include the dharmas.
This explanation is good.
Question:
How many kinds of heat are there?
Up to how many kinds of supreme worldly dharmas are there?
Answer:
Some say that the heat dharma has three kinds: lower-lower, lower-middle, and lower-upper.
The peak dharma has three kinds:
middle-lower, middle-middle, and middle-upper.
Acceptance has two kinds:
lower-upper and upper-middle.
The supreme worldly dharmas have one kind, namely upper-upper.
These four roots of goodness, when spoken of in terms of three, are that warmth is lower, the peak is middle, and the forbearance and supreme worldly dharmas are upper.
Furthermore, there are those who say that warmth has two kinds:
namely lower-lower and lower-middle.
The peak has three kinds, namely lower-upper, middle-lower, and middle-middle.
The forbearance dharmas have three kinds:
namely middle-upper, lower-upper, and upper-middle.
The supreme worldly dharmas have one kind, namely upper-upper.
These roots of goodness, when spoken of in terms of three, are that warmth is lower, the peak is lower-middle, the forbearance is middle-upper, and the supreme worldly dharmas are upper.
The Venerable Ghoá¹£a says:
Warmth has three kinds:
lower-lower, lower-middle, and lower-upper.
The peak has six kinds:
from lower-lower up to middle-upper.
The forbearance has eight kinds:
from lower-lower up to upper-middle.
The supreme worldly dharmas are of one kind, namely the highest.
If we speak in terms of the three, the heat dharma is of one kind, namely the lowest;
The peak has two kinds:
namely the lowest and the middle;
The patience has three kinds, namely the lowest, middle, and highest;
The supreme worldly dharmas have one kind, namely the highest.
Obtaining the heat dharma is also abandoning.
Abandoning is of two kinds:
When leaving the realm and ground, and when regressing, one abandons.
When abandoning through regression, one commits uninterrupted offenses, severs wholesome roots, and also falls into evil paths.
What other good benefits are there?
One has already become a definitive cause for nirvana, like the method of swallowing the hook and bait.
Obtaining the peak dharma is also abandoning. Abandoning is of two kinds:
When leaving the realm and ground, and when regressing.
When abandoning through regression, one commits uninterrupted offenses and also falls into evil paths.
What other good benefits are there?
One does not sever wholesome roots again.
If so, did Devadatta not obtain the peak dharma?
As a verse says:
Receiving offerings without virtue is called being an ordinary person,
Forgetting all goodness is called falling back from the peak.
How should this verse be understood?
The answer is:
This refers to falling back from attainment.
Furthermore, some say that the World-Honored One is like the peak. He, with an evil mind, faced the Buddha and fell into a bad path, therefore it is said to be falling back from the peak.
Attaining forbearance also abandons. There is one kind of abandonment, when leaving the realm and stage.
Abandoning those wholesome roots does not mean regressing. One does not create uninterrupted karma, nor does one sever wholesome roots.
What other good benefits are there?
One does not fall into bad paths.
Attaining the supreme worldly dharmas also abandons. There is one kind of abandonment, when leaving the realm and stage, abandoning without regressing.
Why is this?
This nature of wholesome roots is not regressing. One does not create uninterrupted karma, nor does one sever wholesome roots, nor does one fall into bad paths.
What other good benefits are there?
One subsequently attains correct determination.
There is also an explanation that one who has attained the stage of heat also abandons it, and abandonment is of two kinds:
When leaving the realm of desire and when regressing.
Abandonment at the time of regression leads to falling into evil realms by committing uninterrupted offenses.
What further good benefits are there?
Only not severing the roots of goodness.
If so, Devadatta did not attain the stage of heat.
Why is it so?
Because he severed the roots of goodness.
One who has attained the stage of summit also abandons it, and abandonment is of two kinds:
When leaving the realm of desire and when regressing.
Abandonment at the time of regression leads to falling into evil realms.
What further good benefits are there?
Not committing uninterrupted offenses, not severing the roots of goodness.
One who has attained the stage of patience also abandons it, and abandonment is of one kind, when leaving the realm of desire.
Those roots of goodness are irreversible, not committing uninterrupted offenses, not severing the roots of goodness, not falling into evil realms.
What further good benefits are there?
Not being attached to the self.
Question:
If so, Åšá¹›Ä«gupta, AngulimÄla, and Saccaka the son of Nigan.tha would have attained acceptance.
Why is it so?
Because they are attached to the self.
Answer:
They are not attached to the self, they only speak of the self for the sake of debate.
Question:
They compete with the TathÄgata in arguing about the self, how can it be said that they are not attached to the self?
Answer:
They temporarily bring forth the view of self without eliminating it, it is not attachment.
The attainment of the supreme worldly dharmas is also abandoned, abandoned when leaving the realm and stage, the rest is as explained before.

Westerners make this treatise, saying that the roots of goodness of warmth have what meaning, what basis, what causes and conditions, what dharmas, what fruits, what basis, what retribution, what benefits, how many practices, what names arise, what meanings arise, is it the wisdom of hearing, is it the wisdom of thought, is it the wisdom of cultivation, is it bound to the desire realm, is it bound to the form and formless realms, is it with initial and sustained thought, is it without initial thought but with sustained thought, is it without initial and sustained thought,

is it associated with the faculty of pleasure, is it associated with the faculties of joy and equanimity, is it one mind or many minds, does it regress or not regress, up to the supreme worldly dharmas are also like this.
Question:
What is the meaning of warmth?
Answer:
All the roots of goodness such as giving, upholding precepts, up to supreme patience, are all dedicated to liberation, this is its meaning.
As for what it is based on, it arises based on the concentrations of the form realm.
What are the causes and conditions? The wholesome roots that arise before the stage are similar causes.
What dharmas are the conditions? They are the four noble truths.
What are the fruits? The summit and neighborhood are the fruits of human effort of the heat.
What is the support? The wholesome dharmas that arise later in the same stage are the fruits of support.
What is the retribution? It is the five aggregates of the form realm.
What are the benefits? Some say it is the definite cause of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Some say it is not cutting off the wholesome roots.
How many practices does it cultivate? It cultivates the sixteen practices as conditions, and is called the arising of conditions.
As for the arising of meaning, it should be said that it arises from conditions of meaning.
Is it the wisdom of hearing, thinking, or cultivation? It should be said that it is the wisdom of cultivation.
Is it bound to the desire realm, form realm, or formless realm? It should be said that it is bound to the form realm.
Is it with initial and sustained thought, without initial thought and with sustained thought, or without initial and sustained thought? It should be said that it is of three kinds.
What faculties is it associated with?
It should be said that the three correspond as appropriate.
As for whether it is one mind or many minds, it should be said that it is many minds.
As for whether it regresses or does not regress, it should be said that it regresses.
The peak is close to patience, which is the fruit of effort.
What are the benefits of the peak?
Some say it is not severing the roots of goodness.
Some say it is not committing the uninterrupted [karmas]. The rest is explained like heat.
The supreme worldly dharmas are close to patience, which is the fruit of effort.
What are the benefits of patience?
There is this benefit, which is not falling into evil destinies.
Some also say it is not being attached to self and not regressing. The rest is like the peak.
The supreme worldly dharmas take suffering as their object. The patience of the dharma of suffering is the fruit of effort.
What are the benefits of the supreme worldly dharmas?
In sequence, one attains correct determination and practices the four practices. It should be said that it is one mind and does not regress. The rest is like patience.

When the heat factor arises, if it takes the truths of suffering, accumulation, and path as objects, one dharma-contemplation is present, and four contemplations are cultivated in the future. One practice is present, and four practices are cultivated in the future, taking the same nature and not the different nature.

If it takes the truth of cessation as an object, one dharma-contemplation is present, and one dharma-contemplation is cultivated in the future. One practice is present, and four practices are cultivated in the future.

When the heat factor increases, when the lower increases the middle, and when the middle increases the upper, if it takes the truths of suffering, accumulation, and path as objects, four contemplations appear in succession in the present, and four in the future. One practice is present, and sixteen practices are cultivated in the future.

If it takes the truth of cessation as an object, one dharma-contemplation is present, and four are cultivated in the future. One practice is present, and sixteen practices are cultivated in the future.
Question:ğŸ”½Why, when the heat factor first arises, does one cultivate the same nature in the future and not the different nature?
When the heat increases, does one cultivate the same nature and different nature in the future?
Answer:
When first born, one contemplates the truths through practice, and obtains the seeds of those that have never been obtained.
When growing, one contemplates the truths through practice, and obtains the seeds of those that have already been obtained. Therefore, one cultivates fully.

When first born at the peak, one takes suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path as present, with one dharma-contemplation in the present and four in the future, with one practice in the present and sixteen in the future.

When growing, the lower growth is in the middle, and the middle growth is in the upper. If one takes the truths of suffering, accumulation, and the path as present, the four contemplations appear in turn in the present and four in the future, with one practice in the present and sixteen in the future;
if one takes the truth of cessation as present, there is one dharma-contemplation in the present and four in the future, with one practice in the present and sixteen in the future.
When first born and when growing, there is one dharma-contemplation in the present and four in the future, with one practice in the present and sixteen in the future.
The Venerable Gosa said:

When enduring for the first time, if one takes suffering, accumulation, and the truth of the path as objects, there is one present mindfulness of dharmas and four in the future, one present practice and four in the future, cultivating the same nature and not different natures.

If one takes the truth of cessation as an object, there is one present mindfulness of dharmas and one future mindfulness of dharmas, one present practice and four in the future, cultivating the same nature and not different natures.

When increasing, if one takes the truths of suffering, accumulation, and the path as objects, the four foundations of mindfulness appear in succession in the present and four in the future, one present practice and sixteen in the future;
if one takes the truth of cessation as an object, there is one present mindfulness of dharmas and four in the future, one present practice and sixteen in the future.
The judges say:
They should not speak like this, the previous explanation is better.
Question:
For what reason is the mindfulness of dharmas present at all times of endurance?
Answer:
Just as the mindfulness of dharmas is always present in the path of seeing the truths, so too is the forbearance.
Question:
When increasing forbearance, does one cultivate all sixteen aspects?ğŸ”½Answer:
No, it is not so.
As one gradually eliminates the objects, the aspects are also like this.

If one takes the four truths as object, there are sixteen aspects. If one takes three truths as object, there are twelve aspects. If one takes two truths as object, there is eight aspects. If one takes one truth as object, there are four aspects. In total, one forbearance arises with sixteen aspects.
Question:
Why, when increasing forbearance, does one cultivate either sixteen, twelve, eight, or four aspects?
Answer:

Gradually eliminating the objects and gradually eliminating the aspects, one gradually approaches and attains correct determination. Therefore, sometimes one cultivates sixteen aspects up to four aspects.
When giving rise to the supreme worldly dharmas, one present mindfulness of dharmas and four in the future, one present aspect and four in the future.
Question:

Just as the supreme worldly dharmas have obtained their seeds, they contemplate the truths through practice. Why is it that the practice of the same nature does not differ from the practice of different natures?
Answer:
According to what they have obtained, they cultivate this dharma.
Just as a naked person has no clothes to be taken away;
It is also like this.

Furthermore, some say that the supreme worldly dharmas are closest to the path of seeing. Just as in the path of seeing, one does not cultivate other practices but only cultivates the same nature. The supreme worldly dharmas are also like this.
Question:
If one gives rise to heat up to acceptance, is it always continuous or not continuous?
Answer:
Some say that it is always continuous and takes the four truths as its object, just as in the path of seeing, the fifteen minds are always continuous and present.
When the dharma of heat is born, it is always continuous and takes the four noble truths as its object.
Furthermore, some say that this meaning is indefinite, sometimes continuous and sometimes not continuous.
Some people stop by taking suffering as the object, some stop by taking the origin, cessation, or path as the object.
Question:
What dharmas does one contemplate correctly in order to subsequently give rise to heat?
Answer:
It is the mind of the stage of cultivation in the form realm, which has disgust, contempt, longing, and does not accord with the arising of the power of displeasure.

When there is such correct contemplation, it can subsequently give rise to heat. Heat subsequently gives rise to the peak, the peak subsequently gives rise to patience, patience subsequently gives rise to the supreme worldly dharmas, and the supreme worldly dharmas subsequently attain correct determination.
Question:
If one is free from desire, it may be so. How about one who is not free from desire?
Answer:
One who is not free from desire may also be so.

There is the wisdom of reflection in the desire realm, which correctly contemplates the practice of taking suffering as the object. The practice of taking suffering as the object subsequently gives rise to the dharma of heat. The rest is as explained above.
Question:

If one has already generated the heat dharma in previous lives but has not yet generated the summit dharma, and then passes away, in this life one wishes to generate the summit dharma. Does one immediately generate the summit dharma or does one revert to generating the heat dharma?
Answer:
Some say: If one hears the summit dharma in sequence from a teacher, one proceeds from the summit;
If the teacher does not explain it, one reverts to arising from the root.
Question:
If so, why is it said that heat next generates the summit, the summit next generates patience, and patience next generates the supreme worldly dharma?
Answer:
Those who speak like this refer to those who generate them in sequence in one body;
If one has already attained the heat dharma in previous lives, it is those who arise from the root.
Question:
If one has already attained the heat dharma in previous lives, in this life one wishes to generate the summit dharma. What correct contemplation and thought does one have?
Answer:ğŸ”½The correct contemplation and thought of heat is also like this.
The generation of patience is also like this.
Question:
If one gives rise to the heat stage, does one become free from desire?
Answer:
Some say: One does not become free from desire.
Why is it so?
That practitioner delights in giving rise to the peak stage, not to the patience in the summit.
Again, some say: If that practitioner knows for himself that he has the power to give rise to the peak stage, he will then give rise to the peak stage;
If he knows for himself that he has no power and cannot give rise to the peak stage, he wishes to become free from desire.
Why is it so?
If he becomes free from desire, my place of rebirth will be superior.
Question:
If one gives rise to the wholesome roots of penetration based on the fundamental stages, is there retrogression?
Answer:
Some say: Heat and summit have retrogression, but patience does not have retrogression.
Why is it so?
Because these wholesome roots are the dharmas of non-retrogression.
The judges say:
One should not say this.
Why is it so?
If one is born in the fundamental stage and cultivates the roots of goodness that penetrate, one attains correct determination in this very body.
Why is this?
Because these roots of goodness all lead to the birth of the holy path.
If one relies on the stage of non-access concentration, this is indefinite.
Question:

If one is born in the state of heat through relying on the concentration of non-access, and also gives rise to the peak, patience, and the supreme worldly dharmas, does one attain correct determination?
Answer:
Some say: If one is born in the state of heat through relying on the concentration of non-access, and up to being born in the supreme worldly dharmas, one attains correct determination.
The same is so for the first concentration up to the fourth concentration.

Again, some say: If one is born in the state of heat through relying on the concentration of non-access, and next gives rise to the heat, peak, patience, and supreme worldly dharmas of the first concentration, one attains correct determination.
The same is so for the intermediate concentration, the second, third, and fourth concentrations.

There is another explanation: if one is born in heat and summit based on the preliminary concentration, one then gives rise to the peak, patience, and supreme worldly dharmas in the first concentration, and attains right determination.
The same is so for the intermediate concentration, second concentration, third concentration, and fourth concentration.

There is another explanation: if one gives rise to heat, summit, and patience based on the preliminary concentration, one then gives rise to patience in the first concentration, and patience gives rise to the supreme worldly dharmas, and one attains right determination. The same is so up to the fourth concentration.
This then explains the gradual Dharma of the Å›rÄvaka.
Question:
How is it for the bodhisattva?
Answer:
The bodhisattva gives rise to the dharmas of heat up to the supreme worldly dharmas based on the fourth concentration, and attains right determination.

There is another explanation: the bodhisattva gives rise to the dharmas of heat, summit, and patience based on the first concentration, and the same is so for the second and third concentrations. In the fourth concentration, he gives rise to heat, summit, patience, and the supreme worldly dharmas, and attains right determination.
Question:

Just as in the wholesome roots of penetrating insight, one should not subsequently give rise to lower or higher [roots], nor should one subsequently give rise to lower or higher [roots]. How can bodhisattvas give rise to them?
Answer:
They cannot give rise to them in their own stage, but they can give rise to them in other stages.
Furthermore, there are those who say that in order to avoid such faults, one should make the following statement:

If one relies on the first dhyÄna to give rise to the heat factor up to the fourth dhyÄna, if one relies on the first dhyÄna to give rise to the peak factor up to the fourth dhyÄna, if one relies on the first dhyÄna to give rise to the patience factor up to the fourth dhyÄna, and subsequently gives rise to the supreme worldly factor, one attains right determination.
The judges say:
One should not make such a statement. The previous statement is better.
Why is it so?
Because all bodhisattvas rely on the fourth dhyÄna to give rise to the heat factor, up to giving rise to the supreme worldly factor, and attain right determination.
The question is asked:
How about pratyekabuddhas?
The answer is:
Pratyekabuddhas who appear in the world alone should be known to be like buddhas.
If many people attain enlightenment, this is not definite, the same as with the Å›rÄvakas.
Just like a rhinoceros, giving birth to a single horn, they are also like this.
Those who attain enlightenment alone should be known as like the Buddha.
Question:
Have the previous bodies of bodhisattvas ever given rise to the wholesome roots of the stage of penetration?
Answer:

Some say they have, in order to block the evil destinies. The bodhisattva who does not fall into the evil destinies for ninety-one kalpas, this is the power of the wholesome roots of the stage of penetration.
This is the wholesome roots of the stage of penetration of another nature, not of one's own nature.
The judges say:
One should not say this, one should say:
The bodhisattva has never given rise to the wholesome roots of the stage of penetration.
Why is it so?

All the wholesome roots of the bodhisattva do not pass through the world. Under the bodhi tree, sitting in full lotus position, giving rise to the contemplation of impurity up to the knowledge of extinction.
Question:
For ninety-one kalpas, the bodhisattva did not fall into evil realms. Isn't this the power of patience?
Answer:

This is not necessarily so. The roots of goodness that penetrate can block evil realms, or it may be the power of giving, or the power of precepts, or the contemplation of impurity, or mindfulness of breathing, or the wisdom of hearing, or the wisdom of reflection, or the heat and peak [stages of the path of preparation], and then with patience.
The Venerable Buddhadeva said:
Blocking evil realms is not without the cause of understanding dependent origination.
What is the meaning of this?
He said:
Understanding dependent origination is precisely the uncontaminated path;
Without the power of the uncontaminated path, one cannot block evil realms.
The judges said:
This should not be said. The explanation given earlier is better.
Why is this?ğŸ”½If the bodhisattva practices giving, he also practices precepts and wisdom;ğŸ”½If he practices precepts, he also practices giving and wisdom;
If he practices wisdom, he also practices giving and precepts.
For this reason, it can block the evil paths of koá¹­is of nayutas, let alone the ten evil paths.
The heat and peak of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas are all able to arise in bodhisattvas, blocking the evil paths, but only not the acceptance.
Why is this?
Acceptance and the evil paths obstruct each other.
Bodhisattvas, for three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, are in the midst of birth and death. By the power of their vows, they are born in the evil paths. The fish analogy should be explained here.
There are also those who say that the acceptance of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas arises, blocking the evil paths, but not the acceptance of the bodhisattvas.
Why is this?
Because the body that attains the Way is greatly distant.

Those who seek the pratyekabuddha, by giving rise to the acceptance of the pratyekabuddha, are unable to give rise to the acceptance of the Buddha's lineage, because they are close to the path of the pratyekabuddha.
There are also those who say that those who seek the pratyekabuddha are able to give rise to the acceptance of the Buddha's lineage.
The judges say:
This should not be said. It should be said:
Those seeking to become pratyekabuddhas cannot give rise to the forbearance of the Buddha lineage.
Question:
When ordinary beings who have attained forbearance end their lives, do they abandon forbearance or not?
If they abandon it, why do they not fall into evil destinies?
If they abandon it, why do ordinary beings abandon it while the noble ones do not?
If they do not abandon it, why is it not mentioned in the Skandhaka and Catuá¹£koá¹­ika?
As it is said, If one possesses a body, one possesses bodily karma, and so on, and so forth.
Answer:
Some say they abandon it.
Question:
If they abandon it, why do they not fall into evil destinies?
Answer:
Some say that the power of those wholesome roots is such that, although they abandon it, they do not fall into evil destinies.
There are wholesome roots that, even if accomplished, do not obstruct evil destinies, let alone if not accomplished.
It is said that the power of these wholesome roots can prevent one from falling into evil destinies.

There is also a view that the power of these wholesome roots can cause the karma and afflictions that would cause one to fall into evil destinies to be completely eliminated from one's body, and they will never arise again in this lifetime.
If they do not arise, how can one fall into evil destinies?

It is like a person taking a purgative in the autumn. The medicine does not remain in the person's body, but either comes out together with the illness or is digested in the body, and it can remove the illness and prevent it from ever arising again.
In the same way, the power of these wholesome roots causes the karma and afflictions that would cause one to fall into evil destinies to never arise again.

There is another explanation: these roots of goodness were previously in that body, like where a lion dwells. Although not presently possessed, the power of permeation can prevent evil destinies and afflictions and karma from arising again, let alone falling into evil destinies.
It is just like where a lion dwells, if the lion goes elsewhere, the other small animals cannot reach it, let alone when it is present.
There is another explanation: those roots of goodness dwell in this body as if it were an old dwelling, while the afflictions and karma of evil destinies dwell in this body as if they were guests.
The power of the old dwelling is strong, while the guests are not as good.
There is another explanation: practitioners have two kinds of aspirations:
One is to aspire to be far removed from evil, the other is to aspire to deeply attach to good dharmas.
Because of having these two aspirations, one does not fall into evil destinies.
Therefore, the Venerable Ghoá¹£a said:
That practitioner has such a resolve, such a desire, such a forbearance, such a likability, such an intention, such a respect, such a love, such a joy.
Again, some say, they have already attained non-analytical cessation in the evil destinies, and the dharmas that have already attained non-analytical cessation will never manifest again.

Again, some say, that practitioner falls into the river of the swift current of the Dharma rain, and does not allow other evil destinies to be created, and therefore does not fall into evil destinies.
Again, some say, it is because they rely on the noble path.
That practitioner relies on the noble path, causing the evil destinies, afflictions, and karma in this body not to manifest, let alone falling into evil destinies.
It is just like a person who fears an enemy and relies on a king, and that enemy is still not able to look him in the face, let alone do harm.
There is another explanation: because the practitioner, with this wholesome root, protects and abides in the place where the holy path resides within his own body.
It is just as the king's men first protect the land where the king resides, and all the people dare not reside there again.
There is another explanation: because that wholesome root is definitely the abode of humans and gods, if one creates karma that is definitely the abode, one will definitely be born there.
It is just like a precious and superior seat, because the place is fixed, one should not sit on any other seat again.

The fixed abode of that wholesome root is also like this.ğŸ”½There is another explanation: the practitioner, with right skillful means, causes those afflictions and karma of the evil destinies to never arise again, let alone be born in the evil destinies.
There is another explanation: the practitioner sees the faults of evil conduct and the benefits of good conduct, and therefore does not create evil conduct that would fall into the evil destinies.
There are also those who say that there is a good and proper mind in this body, not engaging in evil conduct and falling into evil paths.

There are also those who say that because the mind is soft and supple, it accords with and proceeds towards nirvana, and because the faculty of faith is deeply rooted and firm, therefore one does not engage in evil conduct and fall into evil paths.
Question:
If one abandons it, why do ordinary beings abandon it while the noble ones do not abandon it?
Answer:

Those ordinary beings do not have the power of the antidote of the noble path to uphold and control themselves. Although they have the antidote to uphold and control themselves, this path is weak and not firm or long-lasting, and therefore they abandon it at the end of their lives.

The noble ones' bodies have the power of the uncontaminated antidote to uphold and control themselves. That uncontaminated power of concentration is firm and long-lasting, and therefore they do not abandon it at the end of their lives.
Here, the analogy of combining various colors should be explained.
There are also those who say that it is not abandoned.
Question:
If one does not abandon it, why is it not mentioned in the Karma Khanda and the Four Great Elements Khanda?
Answer:
Some say that although it should be mentioned there, it is not mentioned. One should know that this meaning is incomplete.
Moreover, it is also mentioned in the Karma Khanda, in the third sentence, referring to the noble ones in the womb.
There are two kinds of noble ones:
The nominal noble ones and the noble ones of true meaning.

Those who have attained the roots of goodness leading to penetration are the nominal noble ones, and those who have attained right determination are the noble ones of true meaning. Therefore, it is also mentioned there.
If a person has the intention to go forth, they are still called noble disciples, let alone those who have attained the roots of goodness leading to penetration.
Moreover, some say that some abandon it while others do not.
Who does not abandon it?

Because one always diligently applies expedient means to these wholesome roots, if one applies expedient means, always applies expedient means, well receives and upholds, and well cultivates and practices them, one does not abandon them;
Abandonment is the opposite of the above.
As it is heard:

If one always diligently applies expedient means to wholesome roots, and so forth, up to well cultivates and practices them, then even though one goes through birth and death, one always does not abandon them.
Like the son of Mitadala, when he was first born, he said:
There are two kinds of bonds, and so on, as explained in detail.
As previously heard:
If one does not diligently apply expedient means to wholesome roots, and so forth, up to not well cultivating and practicing them, then even though one attains rapid abandonment in this body,
One should know that there is abandonment and non-abandonment in this way.
The commentators say:
According to the true meaning, ordinary people who are born in that realm still have abandonment of the wholesome roots that lead to penetration, let alone being born in other realms.
The question is:
The wholesome roots that lead to penetration are said to have retribution, namely the five aggregates of the form realm. Do they create that body as the initial action or not?
Answer:
Some say that it does not create the initial stage.
Why is it so?

Because it resembles the uncontaminated path and detests rebirth. The other karmas create the initial stage. Those wholesome roots of penetration only create the full stage before receiving retribution.
Again, some say that it also creates the initial stage, obtaining the wonderful appearance of the body and following the path of practice.
These wholesome roots of heat and so forth are of seventy-three kinds. What is the matter?
There are ten kinds in the desire realm, namely:
1. Ordinary beings with all bonds, 2. Those who have eliminated one category of fetters, up to those who have eliminated the ninth category.
The first trance state has nine, some have eliminated one category of fetters, up to the ninth category. The first trance state has no one with all bonds, because it is explained in the desire realm.
In this way, up to the sphere of nothingness there are nine kinds. The peak, patience, and supreme worldly dharmas are also like this.
Question:
Does the heat obtained by an ordinary person with all bonds, from removing one category of fetters up to nine categories, become one kind?ğŸ”½Answer:
No, it is not so.
The ordinary person with all bonds is different, removing one category of fetters is different, up to removing nine categories is different.
Question:
If one regresses from the heat and generates heat again, does one obtain it as before?
Answer:
No, it is not so.
Why is it so?
Because one does not repeatedly obtain it, but obtains it through effort, and it is not similar before and after.
Just as one abandons the precepts of individual liberation and receives them again later, it is not obtaining what was obtained before, and it is the same for that.
As with heat, so it is with the summit.
Question:
When heat increases, after heat has increased, does it arise again from the beginning?
Answer:
No, it is not so.
Why is it so?
Because one obtains the superior wholesome roots, and there is nothing to be delighted with in what was previously obtained.
The same is so for the summit and patience.
Question:
Where does this wholesome root arise?
Answer:
In the human realm of the desire realm, referring to the three continents, not Uttarakuru.
Question:
Can it not arise in the six heavens of the desire realm?
Answer:
It cannot.
Those who have already been born can make it manifest in the present.
Why is this?
If there is a good body and also the correct view of following disgust, then one can give rise to heat in that place. These three continents have both of these.
Question:
If there is a good body, then the heavens are superior to humans;
If one takes the correct view of following disgust, then the evil destinies are superior.
Answer:
As explained before, those who have both can;
Because the heavens and evil destinies do not have both, therefore they cannot.
Question:

The state of heat also relies on a male body and also relies on a female body. If one attains the state of heat in a female body, can one also attain the state of heat that relies on a male body in one's own body?
Answer:
One can.
Thus, one should know that the peak and patience are also like this.
Question:
If one attains the state of heat in a male body, can one also attain the state of heat that relies on a female body in one's own body?
Answer:
One cannot.
The peak and patience are also like this.

Eunuchs, hermaphrodites with male form, impotent males, those with female form, impotent females, those without form, and those with two forms cannot give rise to the four wholesome skillful means such as heat.
There are three kinds of wisdom:
Wisdom from hearing, wisdom from contemplation, and wisdom from cultivation.
Answer:
Some teachers briefly explain the eighteen realms, twelve entrances, and five aggregates.
There are also those who recite the sutras, vinaya, and abhidharma well and give rise to a disgusted mind. They say:
The essentials taught by the Tripiá¹­aka master are only the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates.
He then observes the elements. Having observed the elements, he further makes them into three kinds, namely name, essential nature, and general characteristic.
Name refers to the eye element up to the dharma element. Essential nature refers to specific characteristics. General characteristic refers to impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.

When observing in this way, cultivating this wisdom, and further attaining concentration, he gives rise to the thought of disgust and distress towards these elements.ğŸ”½He further briefly observes the twelve sense bases. The eye element is the eye sense base, up to the touch element being the touch sense base. The seven consciousness elements are the mind sense base. The dharma element is the dharma sense base.

He also briefly observes the aggregates. He observes that the ten material sense bases and the form in the dharma sense base are the form aggregate. The mind sense base is the consciousness aggregate. The dharma sense base is the three aggregates.

Moreover, the brief aggregates are precisely the four foundations of mindfulness. The form aggregate is precisely the foundation of mindfulness of the body, the feeling aggregate is precisely the foundation of mindfulness of feelings, the consciousness aggregate is precisely the foundation of mindfulness of the mind, and the perception aggregate and the formation aggregate are precisely the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas.

Moreover, the brief aggregate contemplation is the four noble truths. The fruits of the five aggregates are the truth of suffering, the causes of the five aggregates are the truth of the origin, the cessation of the five aggregates is the truth of cessation, and the studied and unstudied dharmas are the truth of the path.
Those truths are again given three kinds of names, natures, and general characteristics.
The names are from suffering up to the path.
The natures are the specific characteristics. The specific characteristics are the meaning of suffering as the principle of oppression, up to the meaning of the path as the principle of liberation.
The general characteristics are that suffering has four aspects:
impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self. The origin has four aspects:
causes, accumulation, existence, and conditions. Cessation has four aspects:
cessation, tranquility, excellence, and separation. The path has four aspects:
path, suchness, traces, and vehicle.

When cultivating this wisdom and attaining concentration, at the time of seeing those truths, one also sequentially contemplates the distinctions of the suffering of the desire realm, the distinctions of the suffering of the form and formless realms, up to the distinctions of the path of practice leading to the cessation of the desire realm, and up to the path of practice leading to the cessation of the form and formless realms.
At that time, contemplating the truths is like contemplating external objects such as cloth.
When contemplating in this way, it is called the fulfillment of the wisdom of hearing.

In this way, gradually cultivating and practicing, the next stage of the wisdom of reflection arises, further progressing in cultivation and practice, the next stage of the wisdom of cultivation arises, which is able to practice the holy path.

When contemplating in this way, it is called the stage of heat. In this way, gradually increasing and growing, the next stage of the peak arises. The peak next gives rise to patience. Patience next gives rise to the supreme worldly dharmas. Next, the patience of the dharma of suffering arises, cutting off the ten defilements to be eliminated by seeing the suffering of the desire realm. Sequentially, the knowledge of the dharma of suffering arises. In this way, the subsequent knowledge of the path arises, attaining the fruit of stream-entry. Sequentially, up to the knowledge of extinction, this is called the gradual arising of the dharmas of the roots of goodness.
There are three kinds of wholesome roots:
First, the wholesome roots of the category of merit;
Second, the wholesome roots of the category of liberation;
Third, the wholesome roots of the category of penetration.

As for the wholesome roots of the category of merit, they are the seeds that can bring about rebirth in the heavens. If born in the human realm, one is born into a wealthy and noble family, with great authority and abundant wealth, with a complete retinue, and with an upright appearance. They can serve as the seeds for becoming a wheel-turning sage king, Åšakra, MÄra, or BrahmÄ.

As for the wholesome roots of the category of liberation, they are the seeds that can bring about liberation, the causes that are certain and irreversible, and which will definitely lead to nirvÄá¹‡a.
As for the wholesome roots of the category of penetration, they refer to the stage of heat up to the stage of the highest worldly dharmas.
Question:
Where are the wholesome roots of the category of liberation planted?
Answer:
In the desire realm, not in the form realm.
In the desire realm, in the human path, not in the other paths.
In the human path, in the three continents, not in Uttarakuru.
When a Buddha appears in the world, it is not a time without a Buddha.
There is also a view that if there is no Buddha, one encounters a pratyekabuddha and also plants the wholesome roots of liberation.
What is its essence?
Answer:
If it is bodily action, verbal action, or mental action, it is mostly mental action.
Is it the aggregate of five consciousnesses or the stage of thought?
Answer:
It is the stage of thought, not the aggregate of five consciousnesses.
Is it skillful by means of expedient means or skillful by means of innate endowment?
Answer:
It is both skillful by means of expedient means and skillful by means of innate endowment.
Is it the wisdom of hearing, the wisdom of reflection, or the wisdom of cultivation?
Answer:
It is the wisdom of hearing and the wisdom of reflection, not the wisdom of cultivation.
By what means does one plant these wholesome roots?
Answer:
Either by means of giving, or by means of upholding precepts, or by means of much learning, but it is not definite.
Why is it so?
Some people may offer a single handful of food, yet be able to plant wholesome roots conducive to liberation;
while some may be able to perform the long-term vegetarian precepts and the ganachakra ritual, yet be unable to plant wholesome roots conducive to liberation.
Some may observe the one-day precepts, yet be able to plant wholesome roots conducive to liberation;
while some may uphold the precepts all their life, yet be unable to plant wholesome roots conducive to liberation.
Some may recite a single verse, yet be able to plant wholesome roots conducive to liberation;
while some may be well-versed in the texts and meanings of the Tripiá¹­aka, yet be unable to plant wholesome roots conducive to liberation.
Therefore, it is uncertain.
Why is it so?
Some plant it, while some do not.
If one uses this matter to dedicate oneself to liberation, nirvÄá¹‡a, and the desire to permanently part from saá¹ƒsÄra, and has such a courageous mind, then one will be able to plant it;

if one does not dedicate oneself to liberation, nirvÄá¹‡a, and the permanent parting from saá¹ƒsÄra, then even if one makes many offerings, upholds the precepts all one's life, and studies and learns much, one will still be unable to plant wholesome roots conducive to liberation.
Some are near and some are far. The near ones are the seeds planted in the previous body, matured in this body, and liberated in the next body;

The far ones are those who have planted the roots of goodness for liberation in the past, but have not been able to give rise to the roots of goodness for penetrating insight, even after receiving bodies for nayutas of eons.

The roots of goodness for liberation attained by the Å›rÄvakas can be turned towards the pratyekabuddhas, and the roots of goodness for liberation attained by the pratyekabuddhas can also be turned towards the Buddha, but the roots of goodness for liberation planted by the Buddha cannot be turned back.
Question:
Do they have the contemplation of arising and ceasing? What is their expedient means?
Answer:
That practitioner sees the spring grass and trees with a blue color like lapis lazuli, sees the floating foam on the swift river sticking to the bank, and upon seeing this thinks:
These external phenomena have now arisen again.
If they enter a city, town, or village, and see the men and women singing, dancing, playing, and laughing, they ask:
Why is this so?
They reply:ğŸ”½We are happy and joyful.
Here, male and female beings are born.
They further contemplate:
In this way, the internal phenomena have now arisen again.

Later, in autumn, the practitioner sees all the plants and trees scorched by the autumn sun, blown by cold winds, covered with frost and dew, with their branches and leaves falling off, and the river water drying up.
They further contemplate:
In this way, the external phenomena have now ceased again.
If they enter a city, town, or village, and see the men and women with disheveled hair, raising their hands and wailing and crying, they ask:
Why is this so?
They reply:
Here, men and women have died and passed away.
They further contemplate:
Here, the internal phenomena have now ceased again.

When the practitioner deeply sees these signs, they return to their dwelling place and observe their own body, with the signs of impermanence of youth, middle age, and old age, and in sequence observe the years, months, days, and nights continuing, this is called skillful means.
At these various times, gradually reducing, up to observing the two moments of the aggregates, one arising and one ceasing, this is called the completion of the observation of arising and ceasing.
Question:
Is this observation of arising and ceasing a conceptual observation or a real observation?
If it is a conceptual observation, how can this verse be understood?
As it is said:
If there is knowledge and insight that can exhaust the defilements, if there is no knowledge and insight, how can they be exhausted?
If one can observe the arising and ceasing of the aggregates, then one will be liberated from the defiled mind.
It is not by means of conceptual observation that one can eliminate the defilements.
If it is not a real observation, one should not see the coming and going of conditioned phenomena, yet conditioned phenomena are truly without coming and going.
Some proponents of doctrines say it is a conceptual observation.
Question:
If so, how can this verse be understood?
Answer:
Because there is a cause for transformation, therefore it is said that they transform and give rise to each other, just like the way of descendants.
How is this so?
Conceptual meditation can give rise to real meditation, and real meditation can eliminate afflictions. Therefore, it is said to be a transforming cause, like the principle of descendants.
There is also a view that this is real meditation.
Question:
If so, then conditioned phenomena have no coming or going, yet practitioners see coming and going.
Answer:
When the observation of arising and ceasing is not yet complete, one sees conditioned phenomena as having the characteristics of coming and going;
if it is complete, one sees conditioned phenomena as having no coming or going.
It is like a child playing with a spinning top. When spun quickly, it appears to be still; when spun slowly, one sees it coming and going.
The analogy of a potter's wheel is also like this.
Question:
Is arising and ceasing seen with one mind, or do two minds see arising and ceasing, one seeing arising and one seeing ceasing?
If arising and ceasing are seen with one mind, how can one mind have two thoughts?
If there are two thoughts, it breaks the principle of one mind.
How can one see this again?
When seeing birth arise, does one see cessation again? When seeing cessation cease, does one see birth again?
If when seeing birth arise one only sees birth, this is correct.
If when seeing birth arise one sees cessation again, this is incorrect.
If when seeing cessation cease one only sees cessation, this is correct.
If when seeing cessation cease one sees birth again, this is incorrect.
If one sees birth with one mind and sees cessation with one mind, then there is no observation of birth and cessation.
Answer:
One should say:
One mind sees birth, one mind sees cessation.
Question:
If so, then there is no observation of birth and cessation.
Answer:
This refers to the observation of the continuous arising and ceasing within one life, not to a single moment.
